docs.title: What You Get
docs.text:
Multi-Tenancy

Complete isolation of agents, workflows, data, and conversations. Mix system-scoped and tenant-scoped deployments as needed.

Event-Driven Execution

Trigger agents with user messages, webhooks, cron schedules, or timers. Built-in routing and retries.

Long-Running Workflows

Built on Temporal for workflows that run for days, months, or longer with automatic retry, recovery, and resumption.

Distributed Execution

Stateless activities with automatic load balancing. Scale by adding workers. Fault-tolerant by design.

Human-in-the-Loop

Workflows pause for human input—hours, days, or weeks—then automatically resume. Task creation, draft approvals, and audit trails.

Knowledge Store

Versioned repository for prompts and domain knowledge. Agents can read, write, and update their own prompts over time.

Communication

Secure async messaging with WebSocket, SSE, or REST. API keys or OIDC auth. Multi-conversation and topic-based organization.

Observability

Built-in logging, metrics, and audit trails. OpenTelemetry support for distributed tracing. Real-time alerts and compliance tracking.

Use as Microservice

Admin APIs for headless operation. Build your own UI, white-label the platform, or embed into existing products.

docs.title: Build Anywhere, Manage Everywhere
docs.text: Xians takes a fundamentally different approach to AI agents. We don't lock you into a proprietary framework or force you to rebuild your agents. Instead, Xians is an agent management and operational platform that lets you build agents with any framework you choose—Microsoft Agent Framework (MAF), LangChain, Semantic Kernel, or even raw OpenAI SDK—and provides the production-grade infrastructure to deploy, manage, and scale them.

docs.title: The Problem Xians Solves
docs.text: Building an AI agent is one thing. Operating it in production is another entirely.

docs.title: The Challenge with Agent Frameworks
docs.text:
Most agent frameworks focus on the development experience:

  • They help you build sophisticated reasoning loops
  • They provide tools and prompt management
  • They offer local testing and debugging

But when you're ready for production, you face critical questions:

  • How do I deploy multiple agents across different tenants?
  • How do I handle message routing and conversation state?
  • How do I schedule agent tasks and manage workflows?
  • How do I monitor performance and handle failures?
  • How do I integrate with my existing systems via webhooks and APIs?

This is where Xians comes in.

docs.title: Xians: Your Agent Management Plane
docs.text: Think of Xians as the control plane for your AI agents—the operational infrastructure that sits between your agent logic and your users, handling all the complexity of production deployment.

docs.title: What Xians Provides
docs.text:
1. Agent Registration & Identity

Your agents, built with any framework, register with Xians to get:

  • Unique identity and authentication
  • Tenant isolation and multi-tenancy support
  • System or tenant-scoped deployment options

2. Message & Conversation Management

  • Automatic message routing to the right agent
  • Conversation threading and context management
  • User message queuing and delivery guarantees

3. Workflow Orchestration

  • Built-in workflows for common patterns
  • Custom workflow definitions for complex logic
  • Worker management and scaling

4. Scheduling Infrastructure

  • Cron-based and interval schedules
  • Time-based agent activation
  • Automatic schedule lifecycle management

5. Integration & Connectivity

  • Webhook triggers and callbacks
  • Event streaming and notifications
  • API-first architecture for external systems

docs.title: The Separation of Concerns
docs.text:
Xians embraces a clean architectural principle:

Your Code (Agent Logic)

  • Build with ANY framework: MAF, LangChain, Semantic Kernel, OpenAI SDK
  • Implement your AI reasoning, tools, and business logic
  • Test and iterate locally with your preferred tooling

Xians Platform (Operations)

  • Register your agent with Xians
  • Define workflows and message handlers
  • Configure schedules and integrations
  • Deploy and scale across tenants

Quick Start: Connecting Your Agent
docs.text: Here's how you connect an agent built with any framework to Xians:

docs.title: Step 1: Build Your Agent Logic
docs.text:
Use your preferred framework to implement the AI logic:

C#
// Your agent implementation - use ANY framework!
// This example uses OpenAI SDK, but could be MAF, LangChain, etc.
public class ConversationalAgent
{
    public static async Task<string> ProcessMessageAsync(
        IUserMessageContext context, 
        string openAiApiKey)
    {
        // Your AI logic here - framework agnostic
        var client = new OpenAIClient(openAiApiKey);
        var response = await client.GetChatCompletionAsync(
            model: "gpt-4",
            messages: BuildMessages(context)
        );

        return response.Content;
    }
}

docs.title: Step 2: Register with Xians & Define Workflows
docs.text:
Connect your agent to Xians operational infrastructure:

C#
// Register the agent
var agent = xiansPlatform.Agents.Register(new XiansAgentRegistration
{
    Name = "CustomerSupportAgent",
    SystemScoped = true
});

// Define workflow for handling user messages
var conversationalWorkflow = agent.Workflows.DefineBuiltIn(
    name: "Conversational", 
    workers: 1
);

// Connect your agent logic to the workflow
conversationalWorkflow.OnUserMessage(async (context) =>
{
    // Call YOUR agent implementation (any framework)
    var response = await ConversationalAgent.ProcessMessageAsync(
        context, 
        openAiApiKey
    );

    // Xians handles message delivery, threading, and state
    await context.ReplyAsync(response);
});

docs.title: Step 3: Add Schedules (Optional)
docs.text:
Enable time-based agent activation:

// Define a custom workflow for scheduled tasks
var scheduledWorkflow = agent.Workflows.DefineCustom<DailyReportWorkflow>(
    workers: 1

// Xians automatically provides schedule infrastructure

await scheduledWorkflow.Schedules
    .Create("daily-report")
    .WithCronSchedule("0 9 * * *")  // 9 AM daily
    .StartAsync();

docs.title: Step 4: Run Your Agent
Pattern 1: Multi-Workflow Agent
docs.text:
One agent, multiple specialized workflows.

C#
// Single agent with different workflows for different use cases
var agent = xiansPlatform.Agents.Register(new XiansAgentRegistration
{
    Name = "CustomerServiceHub",
    SystemScoped = true
});

// Conversational workflow for chat interactions
var chatWorkflow = agent.Workflows.DefineBuiltIn("Conversational", workers: 3);

// Web workflow for web-based interactions
var webWorkflow = agent.Workflows.DefineBuiltIn("Web", workers: 2);

// Custom workflow for background research
var researchWorkflow = agent.Workflows.DefineCustom<ResearchWorkflow>(workers: 1);

Use Case: Different interaction patterns for the same logical agent (chat, web, scheduled tasks).

docs.title: Pattern 2: Multi-Tenant Deployment
docs.text:
Same agent logic, isolated per tenant.

C#
// System-scoped agent serves ALL tenants
var agent = xiansPlatform.Agents.Register(new XiansAgentRegistration
{
    Name = "SharedAssistant",
    SystemScoped = true  // Xians handles tenant isolation
});

// Each tenant gets isolated conversations, data, and context
// Your agent logic remains the same
conversationalWorkflow.OnUserMessage(async (context) =>
{
    // context.TenantId automatically provided by Xians
    var response = await ProcessWithTenantContext(context);
    await context.ReplyAsync(response);
});

Use Case: SaaS applications where each customer needs their own agent instance.

docs.title: Pattern 3: Framework Agnostic
docs.text:
Mix and match frameworks in the same deployment.

C#
// One workflow using Microsoft Agent Framework
var mafWorkflow = agent.Workflows.DefineBuiltIn("MAF-Powered", workers: 1);
mafWorkflow.OnUserMessage(async (context) =>
{
    var response = await MyMAFAgent.ProcessAsync(context);
    await context.ReplyAsync(response);
});

// Another workflow using LangChain
var langchainWorkflow = agent.Workflows.DefineBuiltIn("LangChain-Powered", workers: 1);
langchainWorkflow.OnUserMessage(async (context) =>
{
    var response = await MyLangChainAgent.ProcessAsync(context);
    await context.ReplyAsync(response);
});

Use Case: Evaluate different frameworks or use the best tool for each specific task.

docs.text:
✅ DO:

  • Choose the right framework for your agent logic—Xians supports them all
  • Use SystemScoped for multi-tenant deployments
  • Leverage workflows to separate concerns (chat vs. scheduled tasks vs. web interactions)
  • Let Xians manage state instead of building your own infrastructure

  • Mix operational concerns with agent logic—keep them separate
  • Ignore tenant context—always use context.TenantId for isolation
  • Hardcode credentials—use environment variables and Xians authentication
  • Skip error handling in your agent logic—Xians handles delivery, but your logic should be robust

docs.title: Give Your Agents Domain Expertise
docs.text: LLMs are smart, but they don't know your business. Your products, your policies, your documentation. Knowledge bases solve this through Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG)—letting agents search your content and ground their answers in your truth.

docs.title: The Hallucination Problem
docs.text:
Raw LLM: Text Only

User: "What's your return policy?"
Agent: "I think it's probably 30 days..." ← Made it up
User: "How much does the Pro plan cost?"
Agent: "Around $50/month I believe..." ← Guessing

With Knowledge Base: Text Only

User: "What's your return policy?"
Agent searches knowledge base → Finds policy doc
Agent: "Our return policy allows returns within 60 days..." ← Accurate

User: "How much does the Pro plan cost?"
Agent searches knowledge base → Finds pricing
Agent: "The Pro plan is $49/month, billed annually..." ← Factual

docs.title: The Challenge: LLMs Don't Know Your Content
docs.text:
• Training data ends months/years ago
  • Doesn't include your docs, products, policies
  • Can't access real-time information
  • Makes up plausible-sounding lies (hallucinations)

docs.title: The Solution: Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG)
docs.text: Knowledge bases provide: - Semantic Search: Find relevant content by meaning, not just keywords - Grounded Responses: Answers based on your actual documents - Always Current: Update docs, agent knows immediately - Source Citations: See exactly what the agent used

3. Search knowledge base for similar content

   ↓
5. LLM generates answer using retrieved context

6. Response grounded in your documents

docs.title: The Communication Fabric
docs.text: Think of messages as the nervous system of your AI application. They're not just text going back and forth—they're the conversational memory that makes your agents intelligent, contextual, and truly helpful.

docs.title: The Context Problem
docs.text:
Here's what breaks most AI chatbots:

Traditional Chatbots: Text Only

User: "I need help with my order"
Bot: "What order number?"
User: "The one from yesterday"
Bot: "I don't see any order" ← Forgot everything

With Message Threading: Text Only

User: "I need help with my order"
Bot: "I see you have order #12345 from yesterday. What do you need help with?"
User: "Change the shipping address"
Bot: "I'll update order #12345 for you" ← Remembers context

docs.title: The Challenge: Stateless LLMs
docs.text: LLMs don't remember conversations. Every interaction is isolated unless you manually manage context.

docs.title: The Solution: Message Threads
docs.text: Messages in Xians.ai provide: - Persistent Memory: Conversations survive across sessions - Contextual Understanding: Agents see the full history - Multi-Turn Dialogues: Complex conversations that build on previous exchanges - Rich Data Exchange: Not just text—structured data, files, actions

docs.title: Time-Based AI Automation
docs.text: Your agents shouldn't just react—they should proactively work while you sleep. Schedules let you automate agents and workflows to run at specific times, turning your AI from reactive to autonomous.

docs.title: The Timing Problem

→ Remember to run the daily report... forgot again
→ Process overnight data... at 3 AM? Who's awake?
→ Send weekly summaries... missed last week

With Schedules: Text Only

→ Reports generate automatically every morning at 9 AM
→ Data processing runs every night at 2 AM
→ Weekly summaries sent every Friday at 5 PM
→ You do nothing. It just works.

docs.title: The Challenge: AI Agents Are Reactive

docs.title: The Solution: Time-Based Orchestration

docs.text:

docs.text: Building a SaaS AI application? You need to serve multiple customers on the same platform without their data, agents, or costs bleeding together. That's where tenants come in—complete isolation for each customer, all on one infrastructure.

→ Operations nightmare + massive costs

With Tenants: Text Only

docs.title: Why Tenants Matter for AI Development

docs.text: When you're building AI agents as a service, you need: - Complete data isolation (Customer A never sees Customer B's data) - Resource boundaries (One customer can't exhaust resources) - Custom configurations (Different models, prompts, permissions per customer) - Cost tracking (Know exactly what each customer costs)

docs.title: The Solution: Tenant Architecture

docs.title: Event-Driven AI Integration
docs.text: Your agents need to react to the real world. When a customer makes a purchase, when code gets pushed, when a support ticket arrives—webhooks let your AI respond instantly to external events and notify other systems when work is done.

docs.title: The Integration Problem
docs.text:
Polling (The Old Way): Text Only

Every 5 minutes: "Any new orders?" → 🔍 Check API
"Any new tickets?" → 🔍 Check API
"Any new payments?" → 🔍 Check API

Slow. Inefficient. Delayed responses.

Webhooks (The Modern Way): Text Only

Order created → Webhook fires → Agent processes immediately
Ticket opened → Webhook fires → Agent responds in seconds
Payment received → Webhook fires → Workflow starts instantly

Fast. Efficient. Real-time.

docs.title: The Challenge: AI Agents Living in a Vacuum
docs.text: Agents are powerful, but they need to connect with the outside world: - React to events from other systems (Stripe, GitHub, Salesforce) - Notify external services when work completes - Integrate with existing tools and workflows

docs.title: The Solution: Event-Driven Architecture
docs.text: Webhooks provide: - Instant Reactions: Trigger agents the moment something happens - Bi-Directional Integration: Receive events AND send notifications - Loose Coupling: Integrate without tight API dependencies - Scalability: Handle thousands of events per second

✅ Idempotent Handlers TypeScript

// Store webhook IDs to prevent duplicate processing
handler: async (event) => {
  const alreadyProcessed = await db.exists("webhook_id", event.id);
  if (alreadyProcessed) return { status: "duplicate" };

  await processEvent(event);
  await db.save("webhook_id", event.id);
}

✅ Fast Response, Async Processing TypeScript

  // Queue for background processing
  await queue.add("process-webhook", event);

  // Respond quickly (< 3 seconds)

    type: event.type,

    await processEvent(event);

    console.error("Webhook processing failed:", error);

The Bottom Line: Webhooks make your AI agents reactive to the real world. They're the bridge between your intelligent agents and the events that should trigger them—instantly, reliably, at scale.

docs.title: Orchestration for the AI Age
docs.text: Imagine you need to onboard a new customer. Simple, right? Except it involves validating their data, creating accounts across three systems, sending personalized emails, scheduling follow-ups, and handling edge cases. Traditional automation breaks. Humans get overwhelmed. Workflows with AI agents adapt.

docs.title: The Orchestration Problem
docs.text:
Here's why most automation fails:

Traditional Workflows: Text Only

If X then Y → Rigid, brittle
Can't handle exceptions → Requires human intervention
No learning → Same mistakes repeatedly

AI Agent Workflows: Text Only

Agent analyzes situation → Adapts to context
Handles ambiguity → Makes intelligent decisions
Learns from patterns → Improves over time

docs.title: Challenge: Individual agents are powerful but limited
docs.text: A single agent is great at one task. But real business processes require coordination, sequencing, and conditional logic.

docs.title: Solution: Workflow orchestration
docs.text: Workflows let you: - Chain agents into sophisticated processes - Branch based on outcomes, not just hardcoded rules - Handle failures gracefully with retries and fallbacks - Parallelize work for speed - Maintain state across complex, multi-step operations

docs.title: Workflows Are Process Blueprints
Execution Flow
docs.text:
Text Only
Start → Review (AI decides) → 
        ↓ Approved?
        ├─ Yes → [Provision (3 agents in parallel)]  → Welcome → Done
        └─ No  → Rejection Notice → Done

docs.title: Pattern 1: Sequential Processing
docs.text:
When order matters.

TypeScript
{
  steps: [
    { id: "extract", agent: "DataExtractor" },
    { id: "validate", agent: "Validator", dependsOn: ["extract"] },
    { id: "enrich", agent: "Enricher", dependsOn: ["validate"] },
    { id: "store", agent: "StorageAgent", dependsOn: ["enrich"] }
  ]
}

Use case: Document processing pipeline where each step builds on the previous.

docs.title: Pattern 2: Parallel Fan-Out
docs.text:
When speed matters.

  id: "analyze-all",
  parallel: [
    { agent: "SentimentAnalyzer" },
    { agent: "KeywordExtractor" },
    { agent: "CategoryClassifier" },
    { agent: "LanguageDetector" }
  ]
}

Use case: Analyze content from multiple angles simultaneously.

docs.title: Pattern 3: Conditional Branching
docs.text:
When context determines the path.

TypeScript
{
  steps: [
    { id: "assess", agent: "RiskAssessment" },
    {
      id: "route",
      condition: "{{assess.risk}} === 'high'",
      onTrue: { agent: "SeniorReviewAgent" },
      onFalse: { agent: "AutoApprovalAgent" }
    }
  ]
}

Use case: Route work to appropriate handler based on complexity.

docs.title: Pattern 4: Human-in-the-Loop
docs.text:
When judgment calls matter.

TypeScript
{
  steps: [
    { id: "initial-review", agent: "ContentModerationAgent" },
    {
      id: "human-check",
      condition: "{{initial-review.confidence}} < 0.8",
      type: "human-approval",
      assignTo: "moderation-team"
    },
    { id: "publish", dependsOn: ["human-check"] }
  ]
}

Use case: AI does the heavy lifting, humans handle edge cases.

With Workflows: The Clarity

  id: "router",
  agent: "WorkflowRouterAgent",
  systemPrompt: `Analyze the customer request and route to:
    - FastTrackWorkflow for standard cases
    - CustomSolutionWorkflow for complex cases
    - EscalationWorkflow for urgent cases`
}

docs.title: Self-Healing
Adaptive Behavior
Traditional Approach
docs.text:
• Workflows = rigid state machines
  • Changes = rewrite everything
  • Failures = mystery debugging

docs.title: AI Workflow Approach
docs.text:
• Workflows = adaptive processes
  • Changes = adjust prompts or add agents
  • Failures = agents explain and recover

docs.title: State Management
Timeouts & SLAs
Monitoring & Observability
Best Practices
docs.text:
✅ Design for Observability TypeScript

// Always track state and progress
{
  id: "important-step",
  agent: "CriticalAgent",
  monitoring: {
    logInputs: true,
    logOutputs: true,
    trackDuration: true
  }
}

✅ Build Resilience TypeScript

// Plan for failure
{
  retry: { maxAttempts: 3 },
  fallback: "alternative-workflow",
  timeout: "10m"
}

✅ Keep Steps Atomic Each step should do ONE thing well. Better to have 10 simple steps than 3 complex ones.

❌ Don't Create Mega-Workflows Split complex processes into sub-workflows. Easier to test, debug, and reuse.

❌ Don't Ignore Context Windows Each step sees previous outputs. Long workflows = huge context. Plan accordingly.

docs.title: Integration Points
docs.text:
Workflows become powerful when combined with:

  • Agents: The workers that execute each step
  • Messages: Human-to-workflow communication
  • Schedules: Trigger workflows on a timeline
  • Webhooks: Start workflows from external events
  • Knowledge: Equip workflow agents with domain knowledge

The Bottom Line: Workflows turn your collection of smart agents into coordinated, reliable business processes that adapt to complexity instead of breaking under it.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
Xians is a control plane for AI agents. It sits alongside your agent framework - not replacing it.

Build agents with whatever framework you like: Azure AI Projects, Amazon Bedrock, Semantic Kernel, LangGraph, or your own custom runtime. Xians doesn't care how your agents think. It handles everything that becomes painful once agents graduate from demos to production.

docs.title: What It Does
docs.text:
Register an agent (say, one built with Azure AI Projects) with Xians and it immediately gets:

  • Multi-tenancy - Isolation, permissions, lifecycle management
  • Event triggers - Messages, timers, webhooks
  • Access control - Tenant isolation, API keys, OIDC, token passthrough
  • Communication - WebSockets, REST, SSE, agent-to-agent
  • Data storage - Document DB for structured data, Knowledge for RAG
  • Human-in-the-loop - Task creation, draft approvals
  • Long-running workflows - Days, weeks, or months
  • Business integrations - Webhooks, schedules
  • Scale & reliability - Distributed workers, fault tolerance
  • Observability - Logging, metrics, audit trails

No changes to your agent's code. Because Xians is framework-agnostic, you can mix agents built on different stacks in the same system.

docs.title: What Xians Handles
docs.text: The plumbing your agents need but you don't want to build.

docs.title: Multi-Tenancy
docs.text:
Complete isolation of agents, workflows, data, and conversations—while sharing infrastructure. Two flavors:

Deployment Model What It Means When to Use System-Scoped One runtime serves all tenants Shared utilities, common services Tenant-Scoped Dedicated runtime per tenant Custom logic, sensitive data, tenant-specific needs

Mix and match as needed. Deploy system agents for the basics, create tenant-scoped agents for the special stuff.

docs.title: Communication
docs.text:
Async message passing from users to agents with:

  • Security: E2E encryption, EU AI Act compliant
  • Transports: WebSocket, SSE, REST - take your pick
  • Auth: API keys or OIDC/OAuth 2.0
  • Multi-conversation: Users can chat with agents across different threads
  • Topic-based: Messages organized by topic for better context

docs.title: Event-Driven Execution
docs.text:
Agents respond to triggers without you writing infrastructure code:

graph LR
    A[User Input] --> D[Xians Event Listeners]
    B[Timers & Schedules] --> D
    C[Webhooks] --> D
    D --> E[Agent Workflows]

    A1[Text Messages] -.-> A
    A2[Structured JSON] -.-> A

    B1[Cron Schedules] -.-> B
    B2[One-Time Timers] -.-> B

    C1[External APIs] -.-> C
    C2[Third-Party Services] -.-> C

    style D fill:#eea52d,stroke:#333,stroke-width:2px,color:#1b1f2f
    style E fill:#538cfc,stroke:#333,stroke-width:2px,color:#fff

Trigger with user messages, cron schedules, timers, or webhooks. Xians handles routing and retries.

docs.title: Workflows
docs.text:
Built on Temporal, so your workflows can:

  • Run for years: Days, months, or longer—we've seen some things
  • Survive failures: Auto-retry, recovery, resumption
  • Compose: Orchestrate workflows and sub-workflows
  • Stay stateful: Maintain state across distributed operations
graph TD
    A[Agent] --> B[Default Workflow]
    A --> C[Custom Workflow 1]
    A --> D[Custom Workflow 2]

    B --> E[Platform Functions]
    C --> F[Business Logic]
    D --> G[Integration Logic]

    C --> H[Sub-Workflow A]
    C --> I[Sub-Workflow B]

    style A fill:#538cfc,stroke:#333,stroke-width:2px,color:#fff
    style B fill:#eea52d,stroke:#333,stroke-width:2px,color:#1b1f2f
    style C fill:#41c18a,stroke:#333,stroke-width:2px,color:#fff
    style D fill:#41c18a,stroke:#333,stroke-width:2px,color:#fff

Each agent can have multiple workflows for conversations, events, or custom business processes. The "Default Workflow" gives you all platform functions out-of-the-box.

docs.title: Distributed Execution
docs.text:
Agent operations (LLM calls, business logic, integrations) run as Temporal activities in a distributed worker pool:

graph TB
    A[Temporal Server] --> B[Worker Pool]
    B --> C[Agent A - Instance 1]
    B --> D[Agent A - Instance 2]
    B --> E[Agent A - Instance N]

    C --> F[Activity: LLM Inference]
    D --> G[Activity: Data Processing]
    E --> H[Activity: Business Logic]

    style A fill:#eea52d,stroke:#333,stroke-width:2px,color:#1b1f2f
    style B fill:#538cfc,stroke:#333,stroke-width:2px,color:#fff
    style C fill:#41c18a,stroke:#333,stroke-width:2px,color:#fff
    style D fill:#41c18a,stroke:#333,stroke-width:2px,color:#fff
    style E fill:#41c18a,stroke:#333,stroke-width:2px,color:#fff

Scale: Stateless activities, automatic load balancing. Need more capacity? Spin up more workers.

Reliability: Activities tracked and retried by Temporal. Your system keeps running even when infrastructure doesn't.

docs.title: Scheduling
docs.text:
Agents can create schedules via SDK methods - either in code or dynamically based on conversations:

Approach When to Use Developer-defined Periodic reports, maintenance, data syncs Agent-created Reminders from conversations, adaptive workflows

Built on Temporal's durable execution, so schedules survive restarts. Manage everything from the UI.

docs.title: Document DB
docs.text:
Schema-less, queryable data storage for agents. Store customer profiles, session state, business records—any structured data.

  • Flexible: JSON documents, no migrations
  • Fast: Indexed queries, aggregations
  • Isolated: Automatic tenant separation
  • AI-native: Perfect for dynamic agent memory

Agents use it for context lookups, workflow state, and business logic. Think MongoDB for your AI system.

docs.title: Knowledge Store
docs.text:
Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) for grounding agents in your content. Upload docs, manuals, policies—agents search and cite sources.

  • Semantic search: Find by meaning, not keywords
  • Always current: Update docs, agents know instantly
  • Source citations: See what the agent used
  • Multi-source: Connect multiple knowledge bases

Transforms generic LLMs into domain experts that answer with your truth, not hallucinations.

docs.title: Human-in-the-Loop
docs.text:
Workflows can pause for hours, days, or weeks waiting for human input, then automatically resume.

graph LR
    A[Agent Workflow] -->|Creates Task| B[Task Queue]
    B -->|Assigns| C[Human Reviewer]
    C -->|Reviews & Edits| D[Draft Content]
    D -->|Approves/Rejects| E[Agent Workflow]
    E -->|Continues| F[Next Steps]

    style A fill:#538cfc,stroke:#333,stroke-width:2px,color:#fff
    style C fill:#eea52d,stroke:#333,stroke-width:2px,color:#1b1f2f
    style E fill:#538cfc,stroke:#333,stroke-width:2px,color:#fff

Agents create tasks, attach drafts, and wait for approval. Humans review, edit, approve, or reject. Workflow continues with the feedback. Everything tracked in the audit trail.

Perfect for agent-drafted content that needs human polish, approval chains, QA gates, or when the agent encounters something genuinely confusing.

docs.title: Observability
docs.text: Built-in logging, metrics, and audit trails so you can actually see what your agents are doing.

docs.title: Logs & Exceptions
docs.text: Auto-captured with stack traces. View in the UI, search by agent/tenant/workflow/time. Real-time alerts when things explode.

docs.title: Metrics
docs.text: What We Track Why Response times, latency Find bottlenecks Token usage, API calls Control costs Job counts, message volumes Monitor load Success/failure rates Catch issues

docs.title: OpenTelemetry Support
docs.text: Distributed tracing, structured logs, correlation IDs. Works with Datadog, New Relic, Grafana, and friends.

docs.title: Audit Trails
docs.text: Immutable execution history for compliance. Every workflow, every action, every decision—timestamped and logged.

docs.title: Use as a Microservice
docs.text:
Everything in the UI is also available via Admin APIs. Use Xians headless as a backend microservice:

sequenceDiagram
    participant UI as Your Product UI
    participant BFF as Backend for Frontend
    participant XS as Xians Server<br/>(Agent Microservice)
    participant WQ as Work Queues<br/>(Temporal)
    participant Agent as AI Agent Runtime

    UI->>BFF: User Request
    BFF->>XS: API Call (Admin/User API)
    XS->>WQ: Queue Message/Workflow/Signal

    Note over WQ,Agent: Agent Workers Poll for Work

    Agent->>WQ: Poll for Messages
    WQ->>Agent: Deliver Work Item
    Agent->>Agent: Process (LLM Inference, etc.)
    Agent->>XS: Report Results/Status
    XS->>BFF: Response
    BFF->>UI: Display Results

    Note over UI,Agent: Agents continuously poll work queues<br/>for messages, signals, and tasks

Build your own UI, white-label the whole thing, or embed agents into existing products. Xians handles the orchestration infrastructure while you focus on your product.

docs.title: In Short
docs.text:
Xians is the infrastructure layer for agents. Keep your agent code focused on AI logic. Let Xians handle the production plumbing: multi-tenancy, communication, workflows, data storage, scheduling, observability, and human collaboration.

Not another agent framework. The control plane that makes your agents production-ready.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: This guide will help you create your first AI agent using Xians.ai in just a few minutes.

docs.title: Step 1: Initialize a New Project
docs.text:
Create a new directory for your agent project:

Bash
mkdir my-first-agent
cd my-first-agent
xians init

This will create the basic project structure:

Text Only
my-first-agent/
├── agents/
│   └── main_agent.py
├── config/
│   └── agent_config.yaml
└── requirements.txt

docs.title: Step 2: Configure Your Agent
docs.text:
Edit config/agent_config.yaml:

YAML
agent:
  name: "MyFirstAgent"
  description: "A simple conversational agent"

llm:
  provider: "openai"
  model: "gpt-4"

capabilities:
  - greet_user
  - answer_questions

docs.title: Step 3: Define Agent Behavior
docs.text:
Edit agents/main_agent.py:

Python
from xians import Agent, capability

class MyFirstAgent(Agent):
    """A simple conversational agent"""

    @capability(description="Greet the user warmly")
    def greet_user(self, name: str) -> str:
        return f"Hello, {name}! How can I help you today?"

    @capability(description="Answer questions about Xians.ai")
    def answer_questions(self, question: str) -> str:
        # Your logic here
        return f"You asked: {question}"

if __name__ == "__main__":
    agent = MyFirstAgent()
    agent.run()

docs.title: Step 4: Run Your Agent
docs.text:
Start your agent:

Bash
xians run

Your agent is now running and ready to interact!

docs.title: Using the CLI
docs.text:
Interact with your agent via the command line:

Bash
xians chat --agent MyFirstAgent

docs.title: Using the API
docs.text:
Send a request to your agent:

Bash
curl -X POST http://localhost:8080/api/chat \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"message": "Hello!", "agent": "MyFirstAgent"}'
